string.text: Warehouse shipments invoice. It's almost illegible, but you can make out some products' names and amount. A part of the warehouse head's last name can be read: "...ncha".

Personal diary of a professor; some of notes completely readable. However, it's only worth reading if you'd like to know when the author woke up, what breakfast he ate and that he hadn't seen his family for long. It's also mentioned that the staff weren't allowed to leave until they would finish the project.
Thousands of numbers, charts and schematics. You can make out more than a half of it, but you shouldn't be even trying to understand it without a degree.
The text has already faded; only the inscription on the title page - "Science Project" - is seen. Seems like that was a science project indeed.
Some notebook. Water washed away all the text, so you can't understand anything.
Seems like this sheet with notes belonged to one of the RI workers. It appears that Strelok was interested in this note as it was found in his stash.

Petition addressed to the director of RI to send an institute worker for a treatment. Says that feels bad since the start of the experiment in RI. The RI director's last name is seen - Lebedev. Year 2002.
A book with torn pages and a strange epigraph hand-written on the inner side of its cover.
Key to the door of Strelok's stash.
PDA of the most wanted bandit leader, Borziy.
A working laptop which probably has some interesting info on it.
Research journal filled out by several professors. Detailed description of the experiments. Nearly a half is readable.

Security contract concluded between the mining facility head and some Russian mercenaries. Obligations of both parties as partners are discussed along with mercenaries' responsibilities in case of emergency. A curious list of emergencies included.
Report dating back to the first day of deployment. Optimistic prognoses and details of the work done.
Washed out À4 sheet with readable words "Complaint", "unforeseen circumstances", "central entrance collapse" and some apologies.

Response to another department:\n\n"Are all the X-18 workers nuts?! I don't care about what happened there! Just because the central entrance has collapsed doesn't mean you shouldn't seize all the papers and documents from there! And I don't care what lurks there now. You have a couple of days to go there and get everything that's left; and I don't care if an army or Pope himself would be sent there!"
Financial papers and a plan to build a geological facility. Big pile of papers; the bandits probably used it instead of firewood.
Basic toolkit consisting of common tools used for various purposes.
Tools used for calibration and tweaking.
Piece of paper with an inscription of "47" on it.
Piece of paper with an inscription of "59" on it.
Condensers which are widely used by radio enthusiasts.
Dark Valley map and Borov's personal signs along with a few mentions of the X-18 lab.
VIP card which is given to the winner of the 1st place prize in the Arena Challenge Competition. Now you can get to the Bar as a veteran from its entrance!
The container is made out of a fireproof material and apparently full of artifacts. You shouldn't show it to anyone, although it's hard to break open.
Box with some Gauss Rifle ammunition.
Small documents folder containing the last record of:\n\n"Message to all personnel! The Metro Station's service entrance locking mechanism has been replaced. The new code to the door is: 4134".

Powerful electronic lockpick. Strangely enough, it does not seem to be an all-purpose thieves' instrument. Rather, it seems to have been created with a specific electronic lock in mind and can't be used to override anything else.
Plastic document file. You'd need a degree in biology to understand a word of what it says.

Teleportation; there's few tailored definitions or technical theories on the actual science of doing it. Realistically the problem isn't impossibility, but how to circumvent the laws of nature - a truth, but not an irreversible finality - to create wormholes. However, the research of the other laboratories have yielded "strange stones" with extraordinary properties that - if controlled and applied properly - makes teleportation and other such feats possible! I'm sure of it, even if it a wild theory in my head. I have to write down some diagrams and notes to demonstrate the concept... I can only imagine what would be possible if other types of these "artifact stones" can be manufactured.

Experiment R-0925 yielded great results. Previous test, especially the ones using batch K-3, had the rats die before any profound observations could be made on a live subject - autopsy aside. K-4 batches has let rats take in the mutagen and evolve, surviving for well over a week before they died due to the "shriveling effect" on a living being's DNA. The results, although chaotic, has shown the many possibilities of genetic manipulation for medical and military application. At this rate, we might just move to human testing after a few more revisions to the K-X concoction.

After yesterday's breakout in the animal pens, it has been decided that we're locking the place up and are going to gas them up. Ivan has come up with something that will kill these - well, whatever you weirdoes have been stitching together. Consider this a fair warning; next time, the mutants aren't going to be only thing getting gassed. First we had the incident that killed Dolovan, now this. I expect better out of meticulous men such as yourselves. You're all on forced leave until we filter the place out. Look on the bright side: you can have fun with the corpses.

Ivan had X-5, that lab under the old mines a drive south from here, deliver a pair of test subjects. We'll try out a mix of K-7 and K-9 and see our first live reaction from human beings. But why am I still hesitant about this? We've been assured the subjects are a band of misfits and murders that would be far better off as test rats than perpetual prisoners. While they aren't exactly polite, I just can't imagine them as what we've been told. Ah screw it. If there's a Hell, I would've already been sent there for what we've already done.

I'm done. I can't do this anymore. When I enrolled in this project, all that I was told was the endless possibilities for unrestrained scientific pursuit. I wasn't told we would kill for science; I wasn't told we would be tools for governments; I wasn't told there would be no standards or decency - any forms of ethics. That's why I leave now. I'll be permanently silenced - oh, I'm sure of it - but death sounds welcoming compared to this orgy of amorality. Shame on you all!
Scientist's diary and technical information regarding ultrasonic frequencies.
Worn manuscript in leather binding. Written by Strelok himself. Judging by the headings alone, it might explain some of the Zone's secrets.
Folder containing the passkey to the Lab X-10 located under Radar.
Quite a thick book with a "Top Secret" sign on the first endpaper.
Disc with valuable information about Duty base and intelligence operations.
A heavy wooden crate with the word "Explosives" written in several languages.
Key that was lost by Wolf; it opens a Garbage wagon.
Ordinary textolite which is widely used by radio enthusiasts.
Flash drive - convenient way to store and transfer information.
Flash drive - convenient way to store and transfer information.
Flash drive - convenient way to store and transfer information.
Flash drive - convenient way to store and transfer information.
Key of Milo, a Construction Site barman, requested by Lukash.
Small set of 2mm nuts. Useful for repairing small gadgets.
Box of transistors which are widely used by radio enthusiasts.
Something that previously belonged to Nomad.
Electronic key to the underground Lab X-18.
Key that opens the gates you can get into Lab X-14 through. It was previously stored by Petrenko and Dima.
Machine Lukash is in need of.
Personal digital assistant. Indispensable in the Zone.
Personal Digital Assistant. Indispensable in the Zone.
Wooden box which you can place something into.
Regular brick used for buildings construction.
Regular metal tube used to move water through.
Package for the scientists. According to Sakharov, a sample of inorganic nature is locked inside.
Key to the basement prison located at the bandit base.
Rifle lost in the Yantar catacombs by Oleg Rugov.
"Only the brave shall pass!" - this is written on the map.
Copper wires which are widely used in electrical engineering.
Old and red fuel barrel. Capacity of 25 liters.

Little tweaked beast from some crazy military engineers. Just deploy it, and shoot it out and then find a hideout. It is useful against zone animals, monsters, and also some bad guys can be wiped with this out.
Useful if you are going to blow something up sky high.
Old and red gas can. Capacity of 10 liters.
Green metal petrol can. If you run out of fuel, a short trek to the nearest Petrol Station with a petrol can may be your only option.

A dangerous type of fuel that is not flammable, because it is uses an iron catalyst, many industrial facilities use it in production of heavy metals. The Soviet military used it in the past for powering-up their underground generators and portable devices in heavy guarded areas.
Greben's favorite guitar stolen by bandits.
PDA of an unknown stalker with a scratch resembling the letter "G" on the back cover. The PDA was lying among other stuff in Dwarf's house.
Flash drive with the secrets of the Freedom camp located at Pripyat Outskirts.
Unknown device that blocks psi-emissions. Device has a strange blue shine on its conducting coils. It's usefulness is unknown.

Transfer this to the research department

I am informing you that the antenna (codename of BNA-01.4653.45) located in Limansk was altered under a facility which exerts a psychotropic effect (hereinafter - UPV-01.4653.45.01). This object had already been used to influence human mind back in the Soviet times, but the output power of the antenna is extremely low for our purposes. In this regard, the following changes were introduced:

1. Powerful emergency generators and transformers were created right under the antenna in the basement (NKU-056);
2. The line of emergency high-voltage wires goes directly to the station, for which we used segments of Pripyat Undergrounds' nodes.

The tests showed a good result in terms of psychotropic effects, however, I hasten to report on the negative aspects of this object: the installation was extremely unstable. Unfortunately, this facility has been allocated little funds (regardless of the antennas already available), configuration, materials, and the location of the antennas doesn't let them become the main ones. The temperature of the installation during operation quickly reaches critical; the recovery of operability occurs within 3-4 hours, which is too long: the device actually loses its meaning, and its use at such rates is a waste of energy and resources. Thus, the operation of UPV-01.4653.45.01 is planned to be only half the projected capacity.

I'd also want to inform you that comrade N.A. Lebedev noticed Limansk has an extremely disadvantageous geographical position; however, we will rely on the fact that the Monolith fighters would suffice to deflect the possible threats in this sector.

An urgent report to N.A. Fyodorov


The Kaymanov emitter is not functional from 9:00am to 9:30am - what kind of negligence is this?! More than a few times, I've said that the facility is able to be working for up to 72 hours: you only need to redistribute the energy coming from the generators according to my schematics. However, the emitter hasn't been functional for 30 minutes on each of the three last days, "to avoid overheating"! We cannot let anyone to cognize that: one of the our goals is protecting the plant from strangers - but there's a security breach at the moment, not that obvious but still critical. Thus, you'll have to eliminate any trace of the incident.

I would also like to note that this situation may urge the Monolith people to get out of the control: their psyche is heavily unstable - and if it would be... well, I don't even want to think about what would happen. And don't you say that a 30-minute break is not a big problem! Caution is crucial in our venture.
A.B. Vlasov

A whole set of papers covering the activities of research institutes in the period of 1999 to 2006. Many graphs, records, letters, calculations - and it all comes down to one thing: this research institute specialized in several areas of biology, such as plant breeding, development of new life forms, progressive mutation, and so on. Among other things, there are some familiar names and surnames.

Some anomalous formations are described in the most part of the documents - apparently, it's all about the artifacts. It's worth mentioning that some documents are printed quite qualitatively, while others are mostly handwritten. There's no sign of linkage to any time period, therefore it's impossible to name the year these papers were composed in.

Some interesting hash consisting of documents of different time periods: there are some Soviet ones, which have turned yellow a long time ago, as well as relatively new papers which are definitely not older than year 2006. It's quite difficult to trace the common topic as every piece of paper is about something else.

Dear Anton Vladimirovich!

In response to your request (#411), we would like to assure you that you were likely to have misrecognized one of the subjects for an old friend of yours.

The point is, all the subjects taking part in our experiments are volunteers from life-imprisoned inmates. All candidates are promised to be liberated after the successful experiments outcome in exchange for their participation in these experiments. In case of an approval, all the official documents are issued, and the contract with obligations of the parties is signed.

Therefore, the man who you are talking about could only be one of the subjects if they were life-imprisoned and have agreed to take part in the research.

To sort this situation out once and for all, we would need some additional information. Please, provide us as many record about your friend as possible: full name, job, age, profession, and so on.

Personally, I would like to express my hope that this situation - even if your assumption is right - won't interfere with our partnership.
Sincerely, the X-Ray Technologies legal department head, V.M. Andronov. November 4, 1998
Part 8. Access to the NSA's Intellipedia
Basic toolkit "Young technician". It's hardly suitable for work which needs subtlety, but in conditions of total lack of tools in the Zone the kit can be useful for thrifty ones.
Not a bad set of tools. Apparently, carefully selected by an experienced master "for precious himself". Despite the years, all the tools have been well preserved.

Professional set of tools for fine-tuning the equipment; the inscription on the box says it was made in the GDR. The tools included in this kit are sufficient for almost any adjustment and calibration work.
Small device made by Yantar scientists. Capable of reflecting some types of psi-rays in a small radius when tuned properly.
A sophisticated device to detect, analyze and record any kind of telepathic disturbances.
Prototype developed by scientists to protect people from psi-emissions. Not adjusted. Cannot be worn on top of closed-cycle suits or exoskeletons.
Shipment documents issued when some materials were delivered to a laboratory warehouse. If you manage to read what's written here, it might be useful.
Something about the singularity and the scattering amplitude of elementary particles.
Dissertation on the influence of aerodynamic properties of aircraft on gravity anomalies.
Contains some calculations regarding psi-impact on a "subject of an artificial nature" along with results of an applied experiment.
Description of some development of an experimental scientific outfit with increased protection from radiation and anomalies.
The text is extremely hard to read, however, the order seems to forbid some laboratory staff leave the facility.
Notes of a security guard who died from a blood loss. He describes an endless bleeding caused by an anomaly, that could not be stopped by medkits and bandages.
Metal case containing everything that the soldiers would put into it. Code-locked and seems to be hard to break open.

Copy of all the records concerning the X-laboratories that fell into Sakharov's hands. Thousands of figures, graphs, charts... you can decipher half of what was written, but without a doctorate in this branch of science understanding all this is pointless.
Key to a door located at the bunker under lake Yantar.
Functional prototype developed by scientists to protect people from psi-emissions. Cannot be worn on top of closed-cycle suits or exoskeletons.
Some old device. It was used during the experiments in the Zone. It's not clear if it's useful as it looks broken, but perhaps the scientists will need it.
